nodes.name: Suboptimal interactive physical reasoning performance in deep RL agents
aliases: Poor performance in deep RL physical construction tasks
Inefficient combinatorial generalization in interactive tasks
nodes.description: Standard deep-RL agents without relational structure perform poorly on structured, combinatorial physical tasks such as the tower gluing problem, yielding low rewards, many invalid actions, and weak generalisation.
nodes.node_rationale: Introduced in Introduction and performance comparisons in 3.3.2 highlight the severity of the shortfall.

nodes.name: Absence of relational inductive bias in standard deep RL architectures
aliases: Lack of relational structure in deep RL
nodes.description: Typical MLP/CNN deep-RL architectures treat scenes holistically and embed no explicit object- or relation-level assumptions, hampering reasoning over combinatorial action spaces.
nodes.node_rationale: Discussed in Introduction; motivates need for structured representations.

nodes.name: Relational representations of objects and relations enable combinatorial generalization in physical reasoning
nodes.description: Grounding policies in explicit object nodes and relation edges supports Humboldt-style ‘infinite use of finite means’, allowing agents to generalise across variable scene sizes and configurations.
nodes.node_rationale: Central hypothesis elaborated in 3 Leveraging Relational Representations.

nodes.name: Introduce graph network-based relational policy representations in agents
nodes.description: A design choice to express the Q-function as a graph network operating over node, edge, and global features, embedding relational inductive bias in the policy itself.
nodes.node_rationale: Outlined in 3.1 Graph Networks as the main proposed solution.

nodes.name: Provide correct sparse relational structure in graph networks
nodes.description: Using edges only between physically contacting blocks gives the GN an accurate relational skeleton, avoiding the need to learn edge validity and reducing invalid actions.
nodes.node_rationale: Motivated and tested in 3.3.2 The effect of relational structure.

nodes.name: Combine relational reasoning with explicit physics simulation for decision making
nodes.description: Augment relational reasoning with forward physics rollouts to evaluate candidate glue actions, a model-based planning approach expected to improve solution quality.
nodes.node_rationale: Described in 3.3.1 Design where the simulation agent is introduced.

nodes.name: Graph network agent with object nodes, contact edges, and message-passing recurrence
nodes.description: Implements the design using encoders for nodes/edges, three recurrent message-passing steps, GRU core, and decoders producing Q-values for each contact edge plus a stop action.
nodes.node_rationale: Detailed in 3.1 Graph Networks and Supplementary 5.1.2.

nodes.name: Sparse graph representation limited to contact edges
nodes.description: Scene graphs contain only physically touching block pairs as edges, reducing output space and encoding relational validity directly.
nodes.node_rationale: Implementation detail contrasted with fully-connected GN in 3.3.2.

nodes.name: Model-based simulation agent evaluating glue options via physics engine
nodes.description: For each candidate unglued contact, Mujoco simulates the post-glue tower and greedily selects the glue point minimising falling blocks, repeating until stability.

nodes.name: GN agent predicts tower stability and glue necessity accurately in supervised experiments
nodes.description: In supervised tests, GNs achieved high accuracy predicting overall tower stability (sparse graphs learned faster) and required only one recurrence to improve glue-edge selection accuracy.
nodes.node_rationale: Reported in 3.2 Supervised Learning Experiments and Figure 3.

nodes.name: GN agent outperforms MLP and generalizes across tower sizes in gluing task
nodes.description: The sparse GN earned ~883 more points than MLP and maintained performance when tested on unseen 7- and 10-block towers, unlike the size-specific MLP.

nodes.name: Sparse GN agent achieves higher reward and fewer invalid actions compared to GN-FC agent
nodes.description: Providing the correct edge structure yielded ~183 additional points and reduced invalid action rate from 31 % to near-zero.
nodes.node_rationale: Detailed in 3.3.2 The effect of relational structure.

nodes.name: Simulation agent attains highest reward relative to GN agent
nodes.description: Physics-driven simulation agent scored ~156 points more than sparse GN, indicating added benefit from explicit dynamics, albeit at higher computational cost.
nodes.node_rationale: Results in 3.3.3 The effect of physical knowledge and Figure 4.

nodes.name: Design model with graph network relational inductive bias for physical reasoning tasks
aliases: Apply graph networks to structured tasks
nodes.description: During model-design/fine-tuning, replace or augment conventional policy networks with graph networks incorporating object nodes, relation edges, and message passing to embed relational inductive bias.
nodes.intervention_lifecycle_rationale: Introduced as an architectural choice before training (3.1 Graph Networks).
nodes.intervention_maturity_rationale: Validated only in controlled experiments on the gluing benchmark (3.3.2).
nodes.node_rationale: Directly motivated by superior GN performance over MLP.

nodes.name: Use sparse contact-based graph structure in GN agent design
nodes.description: When constructing GN inputs/outputs, restrict edges to actual physical contacts, reducing action space and enforcing accurate relational assumptions.
nodes.intervention_lifecycle_rationale: Edge selection is a model-design decision prior to training (3.3.1 Design).
nodes.node_rationale: Supported by evidence of higher rewards and fewer invalid actions.

nodes.name: Integrate physics simulation into decision policy for physical reasoning tasks
nodes.description: Augment or replace learned Q-estimates with online Mujoco rollouts of candidate glue actions, selecting those minimising future instability, iterating until tower stabilises.
nodes.intervention_lifecycle_rationale: Simulation agent is an architectural alternative incorporated at design time (3.3.1).
nodes.intervention_maturity_rationale: Demonstrated only on benchmark; no large-scale deployment (3.3.3).
nodes.node_rationale: Best empirical performance justifies consideration as an intervention.

edges.source_node: Suboptimal interactive physical reasoning performance in deep RL agents
edges.target_node: Absence of relational inductive bias in standard deep RL architectures
edges.description: Lack of relational structure is identified as the principal reason traditional agents fail to generalise and choose valid actions.
edges.edge_confidence_rationale: Statement is argued conceptually in Introduction with supporting empirical contrasts (medium strength).
edges.edge_rationale: Introduction sets up poor MLP performance as stemming from missing relational bias.

edges.source_node: Absence of relational inductive bias in standard deep RL architectures
edges.target_node: Relational representations of objects and relations enable combinatorial generalization in physical reasoning
edges.description: Embedding relational representations is proposed as the remedy for deficits caused by missing bias.
edges.edge_confidence_rationale: Hypothesis is theoretically motivated, not yet empirical at this link.
edges.edge_rationale: Section 3 argues relational bias specifically addresses the identified gap.

edges.source_node: Relational representations of objects and relations enable combinatorial generalization in physical reasoning
edges.target_node: Introduce graph network-based relational policy representations in agents
edges.description: Graph networks operationalise the theoretical relational representation within a learnable policy.
edges.edge_confidence_rationale: Direct design mapping, explicitly described in 3.1.
edges.edge_rationale: 3.1 details GN as concrete instantiation of relational bias.

edges.source_node: Introduce graph network-based relational policy representations in agents
edges.target_node: Graph network agent with object nodes, contact edges, and message-passing recurrence
edges.description: Specific architecture realises the design rationale with encoders, message passing, and decoders.
edges.edge_rationale: 3.1 and Supplement 5.1.2 lay out full implementation.

edges.source_node: Graph network agent with object nodes, contact edges, and message-passing recurrence
edges.target_node: GN agent predicts tower stability and glue necessity accurately in supervised experiments
edges.description: Supervised experiments confirm the mechanism accurately models stability and glue requirements.
edges.edge_confidence_rationale: Quantitative results with learning curves in Figure 3 (strong).

edges.source_node: Graph network agent with object nodes, contact edges, and message-passing recurrence
edges.target_node: GN agent outperforms MLP and generalizes across tower sizes in gluing task
edges.description: Full RL experiments show superior reward and transfer performance.
edges.edge_confidence_rationale: Controlled comparison with confidence intervals in Fig 4 (strong).

edges.source_node: GN agent outperforms MLP and generalizes across tower sizes in gluing task
edges.target_node: Design model with graph network relational inductive bias for physical reasoning tasks
edges.description: Positive empirical evidence motivates adopting GN relational bias as an intervention.
edges.edge_confidence_rationale: Logical inference from experiment to design recommendation (medium).
edges.edge_rationale: Section 4 Discussion extrapolates findings into recommendations.

edges.source_node: Relational representations of objects and relations enable combinatorial generalization in physical reasoning
edges.target_node: Provide correct sparse relational structure in graph networks
edges.description: Ensuring edge set matches true contacts is presented as a refinement to the basic relational idea.

edges.source_node: Provide correct sparse relational structure in graph networks
edges.target_node: Sparse graph representation limited to contact edges
edges.description: Sparse edge encoding concretely realises the refinement.

edges.source_node: Sparse graph representation limited to contact edges
edges.target_node: Sparse GN agent achieves higher reward and fewer invalid actions compared to GN-FC agent
edges.description: Experimental comparison confirms benefit of sparse edges.
edges.edge_confidence_rationale: Statistically significant reward difference in Fig 4 (strong).

edges.source_node: Sparse GN agent achieves higher reward and fewer invalid actions compared to GN-FC agent
edges.target_node: Use sparse contact-based graph structure in GN agent design
edges.description: Evidence supports adopting sparse graphs as a recommended design intervention.
edges.edge_confidence_rationale: Inference from empirical improvement to design guidance (medium).
edges.edge_rationale: Discussion in Section 4 endorses correct relational structure.

edges.source_node: Relational representations of objects and relations enable combinatorial generalization in physical reasoning
edges.target_node: Combine relational reasoning with explicit physics simulation for decision making
edges.description: Augmenting relational reasoning with physics simulation is proposed as an advanced refinement.

edges.source_node: Combine relational reasoning with explicit physics simulation for decision making
edges.target_node: Model-based simulation agent evaluating glue options via physics engine
edges.description: Simulation agent embodies the hybrid relational-simulation rationale.

edges.source_node: Model-based simulation agent evaluating glue options via physics engine
edges.target_node: Simulation agent attains highest reward relative to GN agent
edges.description: Empirical results show the simulation agent outperforms GN baseline.
edges.edge_confidence_rationale: Quantitative delta (~156 points) with CIs in 3.3.3 (strong).

edges.source_node: Simulation agent attains highest reward relative to GN agent
edges.target_node: Integrate physics simulation into decision policy for physical reasoning tasks
edges.description: Superior performance motivates using physics simulation as an intervention despite computational cost.
edges.edge_confidence_rationale: Reasoned extrapolation from benchmark to design choice (medium).
edges.edge_rationale: Section 4 Discussion notes benefit of model-based strategies.

meta.value: Relational inductive bias for physical construction in humans and machines
